subject: AI
title: Horizontal Scaling
description: Processing more items by adding workflow workers, not bigger machines.

hook.text: Your workflow processes 100 documents/hour. Business needs 1,000/hour. You can't make GPT-4 faster. But you can run 10 workflow instances in parallel.

buildup.text: Horizontal scaling: add more workers running the same workflow code. Each worker pulls items from a shared queue and processes independently. Throughput scales linearly.

discovery.text: Requirements for horizontal scaling: (1) Shared work queue (items distributed across workers). (2) No shared state between workers. (3) Idempotent processing (running the same item twice is safe).

twist.text: Scaling workers is easy. Scaling API rate limits is hard. Ten workers sending requests to the same API still share one rate limit. Implement a rate limiter that coordinates across workers.

climax.text: Scale plan: queue-based input ‚Üí stateless workers ‚Üí shared rate limiter ‚Üí output storage. Monitor: throughput per worker, queue depth, API rate limit headroom.

punchline.text: One worker can't go faster. Ten workers can go 10x. Scale out, not up.

quiz.question: What is the main bottleneck when horizontally scaling AI workflows?
options: All workers share one API rate limit that doesn't scale with worker count
Horizontal scaling doesn't work for AI workflows
